Click Here to Read More

According to a Progressive Insurance study, around one-third of drivers are confident in their own ability to text and drive – even though the majority believe that distracted driving is the biggest cause of vehicle accidents and more than 90 percent said it should be illegal.

The starkest difference in attitudes is between younger and older drivers. More than 60 percent of 18- to 34-year-olds said they're confident in their ability to safely text while driving, compared to fewer than 6 percent of individuals 55 and older.

In 2015 alone, 3,477 people were killed and 391,000 were injured in motor vehicle crashes involving distracted drivers, according to data from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. Teens were the largest age group reported as distracted at the time of fatal crashes.

Generate a summary:
input_text.Response A: A study by Progressive Insurance has revealed that more than a third of drivers believe they can safely text while driving. The study also found that around 90% of respondents thought that texting and driving should be illegal. The youngest age group most likely to text and drive was 18- to 34-year-olds, while the oldest age group least likely to text and drive was 55 and older. In 2015 alone, 3,477 people were killed and 391,000 were injured in motor vehicle crashes involving distracted drivers, according to data from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.
input_text.Response B: Many people think they can text and drive at the same time, but a lot of people have accidents because they are distracted. This is especially true for teenagers. More than 3,000 people were killed in accidents caused by distracted drivers in 2015 alone.
